thread.title: Garrett Johnson becoming a star for Kentucky
thread.title_full: Garrett Johnson becoming a star for Kentucky

author: courier-journal.com
title: Garrett Johnson becoming a star for Kentucky
text:
LEXINGTON, Ky. – After Auburn escaped Kentucky with a 30-27 win Thursday night , Tigers defensive coordinator Will Muschamp wanted to have a word with Wildcats wide receiver Garrett Johnson.
Considering how the sophomore had just torched his defense again, this time with career highs in catches (nine) and yards (160), it’s a wonder the coach didn’t use profanity. Instead, he paid a compliment.
“He was just saying that he should have offered me when he was at the University of Florida,” Johnson said, but “I’m trying to do something special here now. That was then. This is now.”
Johnson, a native of Winter Garden, Fla., has played the best two games of his college career against Muschamp. He caught six passes for 154 yards and two touchdowns last season in the Swamp when Muschamp was the Gators’ head coach.
While that might’ve been a personal revenge game, this one was not.
“This year, I wanted to win,” Johnson said. “I told myself before the game, I talked to a couple other people, saying, ‘Let’s give it our all. Let’s go do it.’ I was just really excited for this moment.”
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
Game Recap | Auburn 30, Kentucky 27
It showed in his dazzling performance, as Johnson blew by and leaped over defenders to make catches. He laid out for balls and held on despite hard shots over the middle. He caught passes of 22 (called back), 39 and 36 yards in a single drive to set up a first-half field goal.
The last of those was a one-handed snare on a dead run, while tightly covered. Johnson usually leaves the one-handers to teammates Dorian Baker and Blake Bone.
“That just kind of happened,” he said. “If they want to catch one-handed passes, that’s them. They can do that. I just want to catch it.”
And he’s been doing that a lot lately. Through six games, he’s caught 28 passes for a team-high 438 yards.
Johnson had more yards against Auburn than any UK receiver in a game since Chris Matthews’ 177 in an upset of South Carolina in 2010. Johnson gave the Cats a shot at another big win. His catches of 12 and 16 yards – the latter a Superman-style, how’d-he-keep-that-off-the-ground grab – set up a third-quarter touchdown.
His 23-yard reception with barely a minute to go set up Kentucky near midfield, but that final drive fell apart.
“They call him ‘Juice’ for a reason,” quarterback Patrick Towles said. “He fought. He fought really, really hard. All of those guys have been fighting all year. I so appreciate them laying out for balls and all that kind of stuff. They really, really care.”
Offensive coordinator Shannon Dawson, who coached first-round NFL draft pick Kevin White at West Virginia, said earlier this season that Johnson is “as good as I’ve had.” Dawson was too distraught about losing a game in which the Wildcats racked up 497 yards Thursday to elaborate.

You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide “Garrett is a special player,” Kentucky head coach Mark Stoops said. “He’s stepping up, making some good plays.”
And earning postgame praise from opposing defensive coordinators.
“I feel that most people don’t get that, that often,” Johnson said. “I guess I can kind of take that as a compliment.”
But this is what he expected to do all along. The 5-foot-11 speedster with steady hands and a penchant for turning short throws into long gains has caught 50 passes for 709 yards in his first 18 college games.
“That’s something that I feel like I should be doing: just making catches,” Johnson said. “As a receiver, that’s our job, so that’s something we should do. I feel like it isn’t anything extra.”
